title: Cathy Stepp
text:
Cathy Stepp (born August 17, 1963) is an <a href="Americans">American</a> <a href="Republican%20Party%20%28United%20States%29">Republican</a> politician, business owner, and former Regional Administrator of the <a href="United%20States%20Environmental%20Protection%20Agency">Environmental Protection Agency</a> in the administration of <a href="President%20of%20the%20United%20States">U.S. President</a> <a href="Donald%20Trump">Donald Trump</a>. Her region, Region 5, covers the <a href="Midwest">Midwest</a>ern states of <a href="Minnesota">Minnesota</a>, <a href="Wisconsin">Wisconsin</a>, <a href="Illinois">Illinois</a>, <a href="Indiana">Indiana</a>, <a href="Michigan">Michigan</a>, and <a href="Ohio">Ohio</a>.
Biography.
Stepp was born in <a href="Kenosha%2C%20Wisconsin">Kenosha, Wisconsin</a> and graduated from <a href="Oak%20Creek%20High%20School">Oak Creek High School</a> in <a href="Oak%20Creek%2C%20Wisconsin">Oak Creek, Wisconsin</a> in 1981. She was involved in the home construction business.
In 2002, Stepp successfully challenged Democratic Senator <a href="Kimberly%20Plache">Kimberly Plache</a> for Plache's <a href="Racine%20County%2C%20Wisconsin">Racine County</a>-based State Senate seat. From 2003 until 2007, Stepp served as a Republican in the <a href="Wisconsin%20State%20Senate">Wisconsin State Senate</a>, representing the <a href="Wisconsin%20Senate%2C%20District%2021">21st District</a>. Stepp chose not to run for re-election in 2006 and was succeeded by Democrat <a href="John%20Lehman%20%28Wisconsin%20politician%29">John Lehman</a>.
In January 2011, Governor <a href="Scott%20Walker%20%28politician%29">Scott Walker</a> appointed Stepp to be his <a href="Wisconsin%20Department%20of%20Natural%20Resources">Secretary of the Wisconsin Department of Natural Resources (DNR)</a>. During her tenure, Stepp rolled back environmental oversight and regulation.
In August 2017, it was announced that Stepp would be resigning to become a deputy administrator of the <a href="U.S.%20Environmental%20Protection%20Agency">U.S. Environmental Protection Agency</a>. Stepp supported Trump at rallies in Wisconsin, and has questioned the existence of climate change.
